author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Ok, so that's a quick summary of the four main types of comp. My suggestion is to pick one model from each category. One and only one. Forget the rest for a while. Start trying it in various places to get a feel for what it does well and how you can use it to shape sounds, to serve the song. The actual plug you choose matters much less than the intrinsic characteristic of the category

Last thought, 99% percent of what I see online in the form or tutorials etc re compression is nonsense, even from some very good friends of mine. Parallel compression for example can be wonderful, but using it as the only workflow on everything for *religious* reasons is just plain silly

Take your time and spend a week with your chosen plug in from each category. Maybe ask here for examples of different styles in real records, Jimmy Pages' acoustic guitars for example. You'll get a sense for it over a little while

OK, QC time over

Good luck!


@Slow Hand please feel free to edit this to tighten it up

author: cian riordan
content:
* First of all, I’d say don’t panic. Everyone in our line of work experiences this at one point or another. I’m lucky to have a great network of successful record makers here in LA and everyone has stressed about this at one time or another. It’s just part of the game.
* People can disagree with me here, but I would personally avoid the urge to tell your clients/IG followers/the general public that your schedule is free. Like Ryan said, it’s not a good look and devalues your brand. Not to mention if you’re not one of the people constantly spamming your warez on social media, and all of sudden you are, it might come off strange.
* Realize that that tides can turn any minute. The phone *will* ring. And when it does, it’s sometimes a plus to have a free schedule and to say something like “just had a project get pushed out so I can actually start on this sooner rather than later”, etc.
* It’s also a great opportunity to dive into busywork/maintenance around the studio. Patchbay reworking, gear repair, workflow improvements, computer upgrades. Not to mention keeping up your online appearances… new website, updating discography, etc.
* Start hanging out with people. Don’t stay home and bite your nails. You know people making records in your area — ask em out for coffee/dinner/drinks. Being social eases the anxiety and also reminds people you’re out there in the world, excited to make records.

Hang tough, it’ll pass.

author: nachomaquieira
content:
Hey everyone! I'll try to keep it short, but I just wanted to share something that happened to me yesterday. I crafted one of the best mixes of my life  in just a couple of hours. After finishing it and sending it off, I took a moment to reflect on why it turned out so well. (Regardless of the fact that it's a great song, excellently recorded and produced, with a very talented artist).

A big part of it, I realized, is because I'm in such a great place personally right now. I recently moved to a small mountain town with my girlfriend for an indefinite stay, and just last week, we found out we're expecting our first child. The sheer joy and connection to my surroundings are absolutely crucial obviously.

But this message is to give a huge shoutout to this LWMR Discord. Everything I'm learning here about mixing, mastering, different approaches to work, active listening, where to focus, etc— it's all contributed immensely. I want to thank each and every one of you who's shared even the tiniest piece of advice or insight. This place is a treasure of great info, and it's genuinely helping me grow, not just professionally but personally too. I truly feel it's making a profoundly positive impact on my work!

author: chrissorem
content: Shawn likes to paint himself into corners that most people would jump ship. I’ve seen him work himself out of them and come up with the great and unusual results. He’s extremely clever and has a natural punk rock approach to things. I’ve watched him mix numerous times and left thinking I could never make anything sound good in that room or with that approach but he’s managed to figure it out. It’s not always fast or easy but it’s always unique whether you like it or not. He’s been a huge inspiration to me and a constant reminder that we are making art not products.  I’d like to see more engineers following their own instincts and spending less time looking at what everyone else is doing.

content: Prefacing this unsolicited tip with 'always use your ears, not your eyes, yadda yadda' -- but a few months ago I set my Pro-Q3 default to have the Lead Vocal bus in my template as the external spectrum on the display and BOY does help with mixing dense arrangements. author: aidanthillmann
content:
Coming up now as a mix assistant to a few mixers of different approaches/styles, I think above all else these days you have to be versatile. I think all mixers inherently have a taste and vibe that they employ in their mixes even if they don’t realize it, and they get hired because of it, but you have to be able to combine your taste with being being that “finisher” when the song calls for it. Learn when to just push a great rough mix to the finish line and leave the good things alone, but when you’re given dryer tracks be able to mix with a heavier hand and not overdo it (or underdo it)

But I’ve also learned that the mixers these days who can “finish” really really well, who can take a 95% awesome rough mix and push it the extra 5% are the great mixers of the modern day, to me at least. That 5% is so much harder than people realize it is, and that’s what I’m trying to learn and study how to do more than anything as a mixer. It can seem like mixers who are given great productions have it easy and just do a couple things and call it good, but it can be so tough to know how to improve an already great mix.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: I know you asked a simple question, “would this work?” And you’ve got a gang of people NOT answering that question. It can be annoying but it’s a little bit of the ethos of this discord- we’re usually more interested in root causes and philosophical solutions than specific processes. It may feel like you’re being attacked by these questions, but it’s just our collective way of approaching shit. Always with the goal of being helpful.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Man this thread was a roller coaster. I think a lot of people have touched on it here, but at least for me there was no “this blog” or “this YouTube”, which in some ways is a bummer, but it’s also liberating. Truthfully EVERY SINGLE PROJECT I do, to this day, I learn something new on. And my workflow is just the accumulation of all those different little moments. For instance, this last matt Maeson live record thing, there was a cymbal bleed problem that led me to figuring out how to use soothe on the vocal mic sidechained to the overheads to duck specific frequencies. I’ll use that technique more often from here on out, and I shared it with the group here to maybe help someone else take a shortcut the next time.

EVERY blog has given me an insight or two, even if it’s a Streaky video where I go “well shit I DONT wanna do that”. There’s a million different water stations along the route of this marathon, rather than one big firehouse around mile 10. 

Second, this thread feels like a good place to remind everyone that mixing is a people business; you’re literally hired to make sure someone is pleased at the end of the process. Learning how to debate/take or givecriticism/get or give notes without coming off as a dick is quite possible the single most valuable lesson. No matter how good your 26hz is if people don’t want to work with you you’re not gonna have much of a career.

author: chrissorem
content: There is a Japanese philosophy that I really like and try to incorporate in my life that contrasts the modern way of wanting to get to the finished product with little effort.   *Kodawari* is a Japanese word describing the commitment to a personal quality standard when undertaking a particular action. For some, this may be their work, hobby, or a leisure occupation such as gardening. Kodawari involves paying *“extraordinary attention to very small details”* and taking pride even in the slightest improvement.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Yep Rob just mixed Church. It was already taking off so they let it be as it was, then had Schepps do the rest.


I started out as an intern with Rob for a year in Dublin just after the Hozier album, and I remember him saying how when he got the mixes back, for a moment he thought he’d been sent the wrong files - the mixes felt the same, they just sounded better.

I learned so much from him and his approach to record making. Was actually thinking about how well he paces sessions when the convo about keeping artists “under control” came up.

He’s an amazing story teller, and has an infinite well of classics from his time with U2, Eno and Flood. He would alternate between having everyone in the room totally focused on getting their take or the part or whatever, then lift that pressure completely off with a hilarious story. Everyone would get to take a mental break, then after that pause they’d be ready to go full bore again. I’ve never seen albums come together as smoothly and painlessly as the ones I’ve worked on with him.

author: Matt Huber
content:
Not sure how many folks are doing this, but figured I’d share in case it would help your mixing workflow. 

I have my sessions set up with busses that allow for me to be able to print my main, heated ref and all of my alt prints at once. 

When it’s time to print, I copy my mix buss to the alt print tracks and then bounce by highlighting the last 6 tracks, right click…”bounce”

Saves TONS of time

author: cian riordan
content: Im here for the small edits that help a song reach its potential. Im happy to tune a few notes here or there if they slipped by in production — after all, a good mix can be revealing to the artist and they might hear issues they hadn’t heard before. But I take issue with the bulk editing and tuning being expected in the mix process. Now if I’m doing a record soup to nuts, it’s not an issue. Im taking ownership and it’s factored into the cost. You just have to set expectations with the artist beforehand to get on the same page… why it’s always best to hear a rough mix before accepting a gig.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
When I have doubts on a song, I often ask myself:
1. Have I done everything I know how to do? 
2. Is my mix absolutely, undeniably a solid step forward from the rough?
3. Have I done my best to incorporate input from the artist/producer/other stakeholders, even if it wouldn't be my first choice of approach?

If yes to all, then IMO that's an honest day's work. Sometimes things are gonna be what they're gonna be, and limiting factors sometimes are what they are. (And sometimes that can be beautiful in its own right).

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: I do want to echo the importance of distinguishing between iteration + repetition. Putting in the reps is essential, but you'll get more mileage sooner if you also reflect on each mix, take stock of what went well and what didn't, think about your workflow and decisions, think about how you might improve for the next mix.

author: bobby k
content:
Mind if I ramble? I'm working on what is probably the most challenging mix I've done this year. I've been at my first pass for close to 2 weeks, and have probably started it over 4 times. For context, it's a very dense country rock song with like 80-90 tracks, heavy heavy buss processing, many layers hitting exceptional stages of compression and saturation. The most challenging part is that, despite my philosophical differences from the producer's template, the rough mix really works. Anytime I try to strip it back, import my template, do my own thing, make the mix fit into my "mixing philosophy", it just falls apart. I've considered stemming it out with Bounce Factory through his template to then put the tracks into my template, but that would be a zero sum game I can already expect to lose. 

Ultimately I've had to shift my perspective of wondering "why am I here?" I'm learning that my role is not to run this song through some proprietary process I take pride in, but to simply just help them reach the finish line by trying to understand and continue within the process they've already deeply baked this song through. I've found that I can apply my perspective while setting my "process" aside, and explore what small tweaks or decisions I *can* make that get us the last couple % we might be missing. Any previous approach I've tried I already know would result in a 10+ revision nightmare trying to get back to the original magic of the rough.

And on the interpersonal front, I've decided against sharing any of this struggle with the artist. Maybe the mix that gets approved of the 4 that I've done is the one I spent 30 minutes on, but the many hours of me feeling like I'm "failing" on the other 3 passes were needed to understand that this track only needed 30 minutes of my time. Excuses don't get us to the finish line. 

What has been your experience in these situations?

author: cian riordan
content: I went all in on routing folders in Pt for my mix template. I really enjoy being able to visually compartmentalize things. I just with there was a setting that if you drag a track into a folder… it automatically routed to the input of said folder. I’m sure avid will give us this 10-20 yrs from now

author: sethmanchester
content: I’m no A-list mixer but making records has been my only job for the past 20 years. I’m continuing to grow as both an engineer and business. Work has gotten steadier, projects have become consistently better and my mixes have also grown more and more consistent over the years. I think often it’s easy to get wrapped up in efficiency and templates when at the end of the day we have to remember we’re working on music. Gaining confidence in your taste, in the way you hear music, in the way you want to hear music and in your own creativity can help you gain consistency while giving you the ability to approach every project with it’s own workflow, needs, thoughtfulness and openness. Listening to tons of music helps. Speed comes thru reps and doing tons of mixes. I’m in the minority in this bunch as I largely mix hybrid and I’m pretty strongly anti-template. At least in the world I’m in, each project is so wildly different that while I might have go-to moves––templates end up holding me creatively hostage. To me, the people that are making the most exciting, inspiring sounding records aren’t necessarily focused on doing it efficiently and repeatably but rather boundlessly and with confidence.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’ve been thinking a lot lately (after seeing the very talented Matt Huber’s mix template) about how I fundamentally hate what the modern mix deliverables requirements have done to how songs sound and more importantly feel these days. 

How you can clearly hear the music and the vocals were mixed separately, tracked separately, considered separately; Where a record sounds like a drum bus and an instro bus and a bv bus and a vocal bus, because someone somewhere down the line might need to make edits. Great for commerce, kinda a bummer for creativity and art. 

Sometimes a heavier hand with processing on the final mixbus can help those things gel a bit, to blur those lines. When I got to work with Zedd he said he basically mixes and masters all his own stuff because if you were to take off his mixbus schmutz the whole thing falls apart, and no one else can put it back together to his satisfaction. But he’s basically involved in every inch of his mix from writing to programming to mixing. 

What exactly are we doing anymore, what are we trying to achieve with the mix. The how is easy. What’s the why?

Old man yells at cloud.

author: Rollmottle
content:
i think this is where the Youtube/Tiktok discourse has largely done a disservice to people who think "pro results" are just a plugin away. in all but the most anomalous cases, collaborators are an integral part of creative enterprise, especially one that wishes to engage the commercial marketplace. that's not really the message you hear out there and i can understand why people would balk at any number when they approach somebody to bring in to their project.

it seems like part of this is re-setting expectations on what it costs to hire professionals to help bring your art to the world and helping people understand what different roles can bring. part of it is probably a misunderstanding that this doesn't necessarily have to cost a fortune, but it may cost just a little more than somebody has now and all they need to do is save a little more and come back. 

it’s a complex topic with no easy answers. and of course, at the core of it is making sure we are delivering value at any point where we are involved.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Something that resonated with what @BatMeckley said an hour ago - “don’t be afraid to start from zero again”

Especially while you are learning maybe trying a few approaches is worth the extra time when there is not a deadline you are up against.

I’ve had a few mixes this year where I’m toward the end of the mix and have been living with a vocal chain for a while and just pull everything off it only to realize it just needed a little more top end and a touch of automation here and there when I had 8 plugins on it before.  That’s maybe an exaggeration but the idea is lean into what’s great about digital mixing - save a version, try something new.  If you are versioning there is always a way back to where you were.  Repetition and experimentation will help you find ways to solve problems and speed things up for you down the road.

author: Josh Bowman
content: Been struggling with a live song mix where the vocal on one of the tunes has just been seemingly impossible for me to figure out. Tried a few diff approaches yesterday, clip EQ, pro Q band automation on/off for words, nothing really felt like a step forward.. I woke up and @BatMeckley 's posts about automating EQ popped into my head. Setup two bands and went through the performance in touch mode, rode them like faders. Job done. Discord FTW.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I hope we can preempt any need to defend your own approach here. When we pull apart ideas, it’s never about pulling down the scaffolding that holds us up, but sometimes things we think are holding us up are holding us back. 

As an example- I was firmly entrenched in the idea that I should be able to great work on shit speakers. Amazing records were made on KRKs right? 

A friend of mine, the one who turned me onto LWMR, had better monitors than I had but he was obsessed with upgrading. I told him, in probably kinder words than this, “if you can’t make records on these speakers you probably just can’t make records.”

A couple weeks later, the Grammy winning mix engineer I was assisting told me “ehhh, you could probably do with an upgrade.”

That one sentance ultimately cost me close to $10,000, but that not only paid for itself in time saved along the way, but in the pure joy of making music. 

Again, not suggesting your approach is wrong, just a reminder than being right is less important than learning new shit.

author: chrissorem
content: This happens to me every mix, I’d say it’s a big part of figuring out the mix for me. It’s an area of discovery, trial and error. Some songs/singers it’s immediately obvious and there is often the safe choices that will work but I often think to myself, is this it ? Does it feel special, interesting? Does it feel like it lives in the word of the song and production? It’s a part of the work and I think when you start thinking this way you are really approaching mixing in the right direction. thinking about how it feels rather than how it sounds or what your “approach” is with vocals. For me, I’ve seen over the years that I get faster at recognizing when it’s feeling right and when it’s feeling wrong. And if I’m unsure which is often I try not to obsess over and leave it for a bit and keep mixing. If it’s not feeling right it will continue to not feel right, but sometimes it informs other mix moves that lets the vocal than work, and feel more supported.

author: cian riordan
content: This approach is solid. But sometimes you have so many BGVs that you can use panning as a way to create a little separation. My rule of thumb is lower voicing tend to occupy center-mid, and the higher voicings out wide to create a wider spread. Like if I was making a Queen record, I'd probably stick to your approach because the arrangement would be airtight -- and LCR would work great. But if I was fucking with some indie pop producer that has a boner for a million tracks in his session, then it's warfare and I'm just trying to place things where they work.

author: cian riordan
content: But I’ll just say that having no limiting or real loudness strategy during mixing, however you approach it, and leaving it all to mastering is not the best strategy for predictable results.

author: chrissorem
content: I have a real ATR as well as the plugin and I treat them both the same. It’s a color with different eq curves. Some times I like and sometimes I don’t. I’ve had it make a mix really work and I’ve had the opposite too.  I’m thinking out loud here but I’d say the downside of mixing in the box is the amount we over think about the things. It’s easy to get into a phase or template and a mindset of what you should or should not do. I think I can be good to  forget some of these “rules”  and go back to listening. sometimes it’s good to work into something and it may not be the best right when you Insert it and you might have to change the bass relationship ect…  but at the end you might find yourself in a more interesting place.

author: cian riordan
content: I've definitely been reconing with this more and more. I thought I established my mixer 'brand' as someone who builds things from the ground up, a fresh start on the song. Clearly there's been an evolution to things coming in more fully baked, but recently I had a whole record where the sessions came in fully baked. They sounded very good, were incredibly intricate in how they were layered, and the bus processing was such a massive part of the sound that anytime I tried to build up something my own way, it wasn't even in the same ballpark. I ended up buying every plugin on the clients master bus and 'resigned' myself to small tweaks. I totally changed my approach and it became incredibly liberating... to know that something is already so close to being finished, but spending my time throughtfully making small changes that amounted to a 10-15% gain.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Everyone is into intermittent fasting, my approach is intermittent eating

author: chrissorem
content: I think the order of operations is attack, sex, release. You won’t need Make up

author: chrissorem
content:
It seems like you might be spending to much time in the micro nuances of mixing. (Easy to do that)  try a new approach. Make quick moves and jump to something else, if the kick is too….. it will remind you everytime you listen. Try  to step back and listen to your mixes like a ME. Is there too much or not enough of a certain frequency range?  Then dive back into the micro move adjust and move on. This helps  you stay in the flow and to not get lost  in the weeds.  In my experience the music tells you most of what you need to know. Tempo has a huge effect on how the low end can work. Density often determines how midrange and upper mid/ high freq should work.  The elements in the mix should be serving particular roles and that informs where things should sit and ultimately equal how it makes you feel. I don’t think very much when I mix but I react to what’s in front of me . 
The more you do this the more this will lock in. Another thing that comes to mind, is sometimes if I’m feeling like something isn’t right I’ll do a save as or In your example I’ll mute the kick and duplicate it and start from scratch and see if I can beat it. Sometimes order of operations can lead you down certain paths and as other elements enter the original moves might not being working

author: cian riordan
content: I used to really sweat things when this happened. I always felt my job was to elevate things from where they left off, to really dig in -- and when you pull up a session and the rough is just absolutely fucking nailed -- I used to deflate and pull my hair out trying to find ways to make it work. But a few years ago I watched a great video of Tchad Blake walking folks through a mix he was working... and he loved the rough mix. He was honest and said something to the effect of 'I cant really beat that, so I'm not gonna try -- I'm gonna give them something different. They can always use the rough if they don't like it'. It struck me as a sane way to approach the situation.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Man it goes both ways- sometimes if you’ve got problem frequencies or too much bottom a compressor will react to the wrong things, and depending on what you’re using to compress there may be problem frequencies imparted. I wouldn’t be afraid to eq both before and after compression/saturation. 

There’s no limit on the amount of plugins you can put on a vocal chain, so often I approach it with a lot of things doing a little bit at a time, just adding or subtracting things I’m looking for.

But if more freedoms is stressing you out, try this approach. 
Add a comp in the second slot
See what jumps out at you, and then decide if you need to eq what’s going into the comp, or just what’s coming out of it.
Subtractive eq 
De essing 
More compression/saturation
More subtractive eq/de essing 
Additive eq 
Any final touches (limiting, saturation, de essing, etc)
Fx 

Use as many plugs as you think you need to. 

Then go back and disable everything, adding them back one at a time to make sure everything you’ve done is helpful on a fresh listen. 

If you love everything you’ve done but need a little more on the chain, commit and start as if that’s your recorded vocal and go from there.

author: chrissorem
content: I don’t think there is an argument here either. My point is to know how to do both and the business model of doing whatever gets you less notes so that you can work on more mixes is not very exciting from and artistic standpoint.  I believe I should be the moldable one in the equation rather than trying to get people to conform to my workflow

author: cian riordan
content: If the three aren't adding up to something interesting, and your heavy handed sculpting hasn't done it, then that's an easy vote to nix one or two of them. I do make sure that when I'm down this rabbit hole of absolutely obliterating the source sounds to check back to the rough every now and then to see if something jumps out that feels missing from my approach -- sometimes as mixer, our brains aren't tuning into the things the producers/artists are tuning into. Takes a little time and perspective to catch up.

author: joshbonanno
content:
ah yes. we love a good "oh no, im not booked to the wall, my career is over" spiral haha. please know you are not alone in this and it feels like the curse of self employed life....my two cents / thoughts / approach / experience / mantras i tell myself haha....

#1 - realize that currently money might be slow, but work is not. with what we do, we have the gift of creation... there is always something new to make....and that new thing you make might be the thing that later makes not only your calendar less slow, but also your money. 

#2 - enjoy it. haha. way easier said than done...but when you calculate the hours most of us work vs not work when we are busy....the slow days/weeks/months i think are likely just an actual rebalance for when most 9-5 people actually take weekends and nights off haha. 

#3 - without getting too deep in to the financial world and what not... you should 100% work on a plan financially to have some sort of savings to be able to sustain slow periods financially and feel ok about it. once again, the reality with what we do isn't IF they will come, but rather WHEN and how hard they will come...what we do is wildly volatile and while we can make "a lot" of money one month, that is not always guaranteed and you cant budget/plan/expect for that to always be the case....its the reason lenders always want to see multiple years of income etc. 

#4 - def don't put out a desperate "hey guys, booking time this month to mix your song" IG post post, but 100% pick up the phone and call some homies who you haven't talked to in a few weeks/months/years and see what they are up to... don't even specifically pitch yourself to them....but just use the down time as an opportunity to catch up, stay top of mind, and potentially meet new people.

author: Tyler Graham
content: Is he prepping sessions from the client session? If you make a template for him and have him import session data into it, it should take your global pref’s as long as he doesn’t change them

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think the biggest responsibility is to be versed in results. 

Yes we absolutely need to try and understand the mechanics of it all, but I’m a much bigger fan of Chris’s order of operations, where it seems to be “this is the sound or feeling I want, how do I get there?” Versus “ok, here is this tool, now how can I use it on my work”. 

I fear a lot of people have it backwards.

author: BatMeckley
content:
One of the things that irks me most about mixes the last 5-10 years or so is how often they sound like an instrumental with a totally sonically dissociated vocal placed on top. Really takes me out of the song emotionally and makes it feel like karaoke.

I was having a conversation with Cavallo the other day and he was telling me his mix process that he learned, and it was basically “I just go left to right. First I bring up the kick. Get that sounding good. Is it doing what I want? Then add in the snare, is it good with the kick together? Ok. Then add in the overheads… etc. Then the bass, is it gelling with the previous? Ok good. Then the guitars… all the way through the vocals.” Sometimes it helps to just approach it brick by brick, making sure the building is plum before adding another story.

author: Felix Byrne
content:
ime clip gain the best way for most of those huge jumps in volume
once u get a workflow down it can be very quick (quicker than fucking around with 5 compressors for 15 mins trying to get something that works, or spending the next week banging your head against a wall trying to make it work)

ctrl shift is the layer shortcut for all clip gain stuff
C copies (you can bump something up and then copy that gain move - ie +4dB) and quickly select and paste it onto other notes that need a similar amount
V pastes
X cuts (and also creates a fade between two points!!) - this does reset the copy clipboard tho so usually i will do one pass correcting gain and then another pass doing the fades
up and down arrows or scroll lets you adjust up and down by a certain amount (which you can set in preferences)
E lets you insert a point at the current scroll time
B resets the gain to 0

author: cian riordan
content: With mixing, specifically, my ideal is starting a mix the day or the night before and picking it up to finish a day or two later. Nice to have a little perspective before the first impression.

author: Zack Hames
content:
The technical skills are all more or less the same, but you’ll be doing different tasks. Editing VO quickly, using Frames for your grid / worrying about timecode, importing AAF or OMF files from video editors via Import Session Data in PT. It’s more about understanding the expectations and workflow for Post Production that has a learning curve compared to album production.

Oh, and understanding ISDN and Source Connect to connect with other studios, hating when people send you VO files that are in 44.1 and poorly processed when you specifically asked for raw/48k/24 bit, video people thinking they can do audio, replacing shitty sfx they rip from YouTube with decent ones, and being a wizard with Izotope RX suite to remove every little noise, crackle, train, plane, fountain, waterfall, wind, you name it, are some of the things you’ll spend your time doing that maybe you wouldn’t if you were producing music. It keeps me very fresh in pro tools which is nice and I’ve learned a lot about working insanely fast and communicating with clients as well as instilling confidence. It’s a really interesting field and the $$$ is great.

author: peterlabberton
content: For another data point, I assisted Joe Chiccarelli mixing a Hellogoodbye album. He did two songs each day over a week long session. They were all prepped ahead of time, and he was mixing on the console. So he could pull up a session, assign the outputs to the console channels, and go. Once the first song was done, there was a good template routed in the studio for all the rest and he burned through them quickly. Also the client was in the room, so any revisions were done in the room in real time—walked out of the studio at the end of the week with a finished and approved album.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Wish I’d Known This: Reaper (free infinite fully functional evaluation copy/£60 commercial) has amazing rendering workflows that allow you to batch export stems through mixbus processing (or other routing). 

Lots of people here probably much more advanced in Reaper than me, but I saved hours with it this week. Did a batch track bounce from Tools (select desired tracks, right click track title and choose bounce), then dropped these into Reaper and let it render the lot through my mixbus chain. 

Took 18 mins to do 30-40 stems (for a 10 minute song), and I could fuck off and make dinner rather than sitting in front of Tools doing Solo > Cmd Alt B like a jerkoff

author: cian riordan
content: First off, thank you! I love Ryan and his record is just a beautiful expression of his capabilities as a musician and producer. I just had a quick peek at the session and this might have been the last project with my hardware mix bus (UTA MPEQ -> OG UnFairchild V1). Everything came from Ryan very well cooked with his analog futzery and UAD stuff, so lots of coralling with EQ on my end... not much added compression. Looks like the guitar solo went through my old Federal 864 compressor -- which is wild, that thing works on something every 6 months maybe. Some drums went through my old SansAmp pedal. author: NoahNeedleman
content:

First of all, the artist I MD for js Brett Young, who has this exact thing going on. I have to tank 2.7 in his voice. Like TANK it. Dynamic dips in series 3 or 4 times, plus a dip in the eq on the way in. Remember EQ is just volume, so finding other areas to boost will help balance as well. author: GaspardMurph
content:
Usually I’ll prep the session the day or so before, that way I can take care of routing / solo’ing for problems / fixing problems / checking phase / asking for new files before I start the mix process so that when I sit down to mix, my ears are fresh. Then I usually start in the morning and mix until I’m happy, usually in the late afternoon / early evening. Then I come back the next morning and listen, make adjustments and send it over. I feel like the mix really finishes itself once the artist / producer / creatives get involved so I like to send a mix out pretty quick. 
All of this will vary based on: how close to finished the rough felt to me, and the instrumentation. 50% of my time is usually spent on the instruments and 50% on the vocals.

author: popaganda.

The cheaper/more indie the record, the more unique it would sound. These days on the level of sonics you need to be INTENTIONAL to sound different. Records are creative as hell now, but often have less of a sonic fingerprint.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
So for this song I was hired to produce and mix it. I got the stems from the demo and did the production in ableton. Then vocals were recut in London and I was sent a Pro Tools session. I always cut and edit in Pro Tools, so I used this session to comp and arrange the new vocals, but then I wanted to just bring it back into ableton and blend with the existing production. So I bounced the vocal from Pro Tools dry  (no verb or delay) but with tuning and some compression and EQ. Then I used some of the demo vocal and some of the new vocal in the final mix.

I'm pretty comfortable committing eq and compression on my vocals (the confidence of years of doing this... ps you should do it more, it's good for the workflow). But if I needed to go back for some reason I could go back to the Pro Tools session. I think I did go back once to remove tuning on an ad lib that was part singing, part talking. 

I'm getting much more comfortable mixing in ableton. The only thing that really sucks about it is that the sessions do tend to slow down when there's TONS of vocals with autotune inserts (the equivalent number of tracks and autotune instances in pro tools does not tax Pro Tools nearly in the same way). So thus far the only way that ableton really works for me to both produce and mix in is if I don't have raw vocals in there. Hence, bouncing from pro tools works best anyway.

Not wanting to change things just because ……but really listening deeply to the intent and honouring the production and the performances

3 . Less is often more 

4. Curating your tools for the job at hand without prejudice : template bias 

5. The value of collaboration 

6. Keeping fresh and taking breaks

8. Importance of monitoring 

9. Do some really clever tiny touches with soothe and spiff 

…..so much good stuff . 

10. Modesty mixed with total dedication

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Surprise surprise ima jump in with some Brauer bullshit again- zooming out of the vocal for a second, cuz I think the choices you’re talking about making, when made in a vacuum, can lead you to very different places depending on what you’re already hearing when you start adding vox fx. 

The idea is to identify the 2 or 3 things that the brain can actually focus on at any given moment in a song as the leading roles. Song I was on the other day had horns, vocal, and occasionally gtr were leading and everything else was just supporting (either octaves of the same part, rhythmically the same, or pads on keys). So I got those 3 rocking together without worrying about every track, it was easy to identify the kind of space I needed. I wanted it in the same room as the brass, but really forward on the stage. If I’d had the pads up while trying to do this I was always either too wet or too dry and couldn’t find the happy place. The tl;dr is, if you’re struggling to find a satisfying construction of ideas, you may be trying to treat leading and supporting parts as equally important, and you’re challenging your ear to grab what’s really important at that moment. 

Also in Brauer’s template there are a folder of verbs that everything in the session shares including vocals. So you get a sense of cohesion from that, and the vocals have their own folder of delays that are unique to them. That helps create separation.

author: Slow Hand
content:
My motivating approach to making records (when appropriate) is to treat the record as a painting. Like a standalone work that isn't trying to come near a live performance *at all*. It's completely divorced from the real world or the capabilities of performing live. I want to craft a vivid world that exemplifies the essence of the song and shows the listener something unique. Reality be damned. To me it's about making the statement once and then moving on.

Capturing the feel of a live *performance* is rarely a priority for the stuff I find myself working on. Not to be confused with capturing a great performance for the sake of what the record needs. Those are two different things to me.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Mixing / Production: where do you draw the line?

I've been mixing an album where a lot of the parts have required chonky lifting to get them where they need to be - drums replaced, guitars replayed, creative reamping - manipulation that adds up to wholesale creating identities for parts, which in some cases adds up to manufacturing an identity for the production in post. In some cases, vibe and groove now exist where they did not in the roughs.

@cian riordan I was listening back to your Conversations episode recently, re the greatest fear being "what's turning up on my desk today?" and hoping it won't be up to you to manufacture the required ingredients. I find myself manufacturing a lot of ingredients 🥲

The artist and team are all digging these changes. Up to now I've just been shooting first and delaying questions til later, but it's probably time for a clarifying convo. I'm sure they'll be open to discussion (good vibes all round), but how do you folks approach this stuff?

I'm not looking for additional fee - this work obviously takes a lot longer than straightforward "mixing", but I've always done it without prior conversation so that's for me to deal with. author: Tristan
content:
Repetition, template, predictability = reliable outcomes. 

It’s as much about gain-staging as it is providing QC’d deliverables. Both inform how you work, and you might tweak your template to make your life easier at the end.

Be a minimalist in plugins, use less complicated routing schemes and mixing techniques - go back to basics and implement more creative approaches as needed. Most sessions of pro level mixers will be 80% the same plugin(s) because they know how they react. If something reacts weirdly, or a meter is going unusually berserk and doesn’t match what they expect to hear, it prompts them to interrogate and make changes if need be - I.e. rogue low end rumble smashing a compressor.

No one single person working at a high level I know works exactly the same, but they have some kind of process in place that works for their brain and business. Some more elegant than others.

author: Maxim
content:
I’d say when all efforts have been exhausted to try and get stems you’ve only got a few options depending on how “badly” the beat is mixed. But generally my approach might look something like this: First pull down the volume by a bunch. Then usually you’ll want to add in some transients back again. I like Spiff for this to taste. Then sometimes Master Rebalance by Ozone can be a life saver. Especially if say the balance of some instruments are clashing with the vocal or the 808/bass is too loud in relation to everything else. Essentially I’m “unlimiting the beat”. 

Then together with the vocal in the mix I’ll try to shape the beat around the vocal with some subtle (usually reductive) eq moves. Something like dynamically sidechaining a bell on the hihat frequencies to the vocal can help a lot. Or I might also play with Spectral Shape. Some people get good results with sidechaining the vocal as a whole with trackspacer or soothe. Then if I’m missing some super lows or excitement I might throw a Pultec/Bax-type EQ or Spectre on it. 

So ultimately I’m creating as much space as possible and give myself enough headroom to still do some typical mixbus moves.

To me this removes the need to do anything different on the mixbus. Even though it’s likely I won’t be able to push as hard.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I do think this is an under-represented approach to making records these days. Writing and testing the songs before you track and release.

One band that I think exemplifies this really well is Animal Collective. The funny thing about seeing them live is that they were always touring on the material that hadn't been recorded or released yet. So you'd go see them on the tour for *Feels* and they'd be performing *Strawberry Jam* songs. You'd go see them on tour for *Strawberry Jam* and they'd be performing proto versions of the stuff from *Merriweather Post Pavilion*.

I always thought that was an exciting dynamic for a band. Especially for them because they're big on performing their songs in a variety of different arrangements. 

It's very playful and I think a great approach to performance that I don't see many bands embracing these days.

author: chrissorem
content: Lots of good  ideas on the mix bus talk!  I think it can be easy to get in the weeds with the “Mix Buss”  I’ve found for myself that I will try these different techniques over the years for example,no mix buss treatment and only a limiter.  Then I tried the music/vocal buss thing. Then I tried only processing the groups and lighter on then mix buss processing.  What I learned is there is no right or wrong way to do anything  and it’s good to try different approaches out but if you feel you are fighting something it’s a good idea to check the processing and see if it’s tying your hands. The only way I know how to do this is gain match your inserts and turn them on and off.   I’ve mixed with the inflator and had good results,  and it’s also been horrible. I’ve mixed with Vulfcomp on the master (generally a horrible idea  but in certain cases it rules!) I even mixed with altiverb on the mix buss recently.  Good technique is  very important but sometimes I like mixing into something wildly colorful and it can take you to very interesting places sometimes you have to work harder for it but the end result can very unique

author: Julia Borelli
content:
Hey everyone! I’d love to hear how you organize your schedules and your workflows, especially when it comes to mixes and revisions. I’m mixing and mastering, and I have a manager and an assistant. We’re constantly trying to improve our workflow, but some weeks are so busy that it’s hard to keep balance, and I end up overworking.

Here’s my current workflow: I use Asana for project management to keep track of all projects. When something is booked, my manager adds it to Asana, and I assign it to my assistant to prep the mix session for me. Once it’s ready, we schedule it in. I try to do one mix a day (sometimes two..) and then handle masters and revisions for previous projects in the afternoon. But this often gets moved around because mixes or revisions take longer than expected.

For those of you managing multiple projects, what’s your delivery time like for mixes and revisions? How do you schedule how long a mix will take? How do you decide how many mixes to do in a day while still keeping a clear mind?

Another issue I’ve been facing is communication. Some artists text me on WhatsApp, others on iMessage, Telegram, email, or Instagram. I’ve tried centralizing to email, but it’s impossible. So I keep all revision notes on the Notes App in a folder to keep track. I try to do ‘Inbox Zero’ but it’s not easy. How do you deal with managing communications across so many platforms?

Sorry for so many questions, haha. I just had a burnout and was a brainless zombie for two weeks. I’m trying to optimize so it doesn’t happen again 🥴

Any tips, tools, or advice would be super helpful!

Thanks so much! 😊

author: Matt Huber
content:
2 things that have helped me a lot over the years: 

1. Make a habit of scheduling below your limit. For instance, I could grind myself into the ground and do 3 mixes a day, but I know that trimming back to a maximum of 2 is sustainable for me. If it ends up being 1 or 2 mixes a day, this leaves space for rest, saying yes to a last minute project, etc. Also, I had to clearly define what I would call a “successful day of work.” When you’re in grind times, you can get used to unsustainable levels of output - if you’re not careful, you will accept it as the new norm and think “I failed today because I didn’t do 100 songs”

2. Get faster at mixing …find every single leaky minute, every single wasted keystroke, optimize. Workflow workflow workflow. This has been the most beneficial work I have ever put in. My mix time is about 1/3 of what it was 4 years ago…mix more but work less.

Echoing what others have said — get Hush. Get the one that goes in PT and not the standalone app. It’s expensive and can take a very long time to render if you don’t have a lot of RAM, but it is the best thing ever. Some RX stuff for de-reverbing is too artifact-y.

Another tip is I make sure my clip gaining is set to 3.0dB in preferences. If somebody laughs over somebody, I’ll clip gain it down anywhere from 3-6dB.

author: Moses Mastering
content:
As a mastering engineer, I’ve kept my monitoring level consistent for the past ten years—at a relatively low volume. This isn’t a rule, just my approach, and I do it because I know exactly how a finished track should sound in my room at that level.

Every system has a sweet spot, and if you can identify that in your setup, you’ll get more consistent results. This ties into factors like speaker and amp combinations, how your speakers push air—especially in the low end—and how they perform at different volumes.

Many speakers don’t reproduce low frequencies accurately when played too softly. On the flip side, when pushed too hard, speakers often cap the low end, meaning the bass stops getting louder while the mids and highs continue increasing. This is common in everyday listening setups—people crank their systems beyond their limits, causing an imbalance where the top end dominates.

This is one reason why working with a mastering engineer with a well-calibrated setup can be beneficial. But that doesn’t mean there’s only one way to do things—some engineers work in less-than-ideal setups and still get great results. It all comes down to what works for you and gets you the sound you like.

One thing that’s important to remember which i amsure you already know.... your ears perceive frequencies differently at different volumes—this is a well-documented, non-linear effect. The way we hear balance changes with loudness, which is why understanding how your room and speakers respond at your chosen listening level can make a huge difference in achieving consistent, reliable masters. If you crank it... "memorize" in your ears how it should sound cranked. Then when you drop down to another level.."memorize" how it sounds there. You should then find a few spots you can use.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Not sure if this is more #📺episode-talk, but there was chat in a recent pod about finding a good Audiomovers / remote mix notes session workflow. I've been having pretty smooth results since 2020 like this:


- Get clients on headphones (unfortunately a necessity for feedback/delay reasons, but I'm finding a lot of times that's how they listen to most music anyway, so they're very familiar with their headphones of choice). 

- Have them open your Audiomovers link.

 - Start a Facetime/Zoom call on your phone with whoever needs to be there. Mute your own Facetime mic on your phone, but clients leave theirs open. They'll hear your chat via the talkback mic you've set up in Tools.

 - Use talkback mic routing as pictured. If you're a Pro Tools nerd, you can probably work out what's going on by following the routing and sidechain assignments in the screenshot, but:


I print mixes and the limited ref (usually just tickling Pro-L 2) at the same time, so I make a Pre-Fade send to the Audiomovers bus from my Mix Print channel. This is also where the limiter lives, so their Audiomovers feed goes out at a healthy level.

My talkback channel (usually a 57) has a ducking compressor on it, sidechained from the Listen Print send and set to stun. This means my TB mic gets (more or less) muted during playback, so I can work on speakers while I make their tweaks. Muteomatic is still in my template, but I think I opted for the sidechained compressor because delay tails etc were getting double piped down to clients through my mic the moment playback stopped, whereas the compressor has adjustable release so it can come back up more or less as the tails die.

If any of that doesn't make sense, just lemme know and I can amend this post.

author: aidanthillmann
content:
If you set up your Pro Tools template in a certain way, you can bounce stems super fast. I set up auxes and route stuff to them that will be a stem, so it’s part of the prep process (i.e. route Lead Vocal to Lead Vocal Aux, Keys 1 to Keys 1 Aux and so forth), so choose what you will for the song and split up however much you need to. Then I use sends (or you can multi-output) to respective audio tracks and name them (you can also include Instrumental, TV Mix and A Cappella as their own audio tracks). Record-enable all the audio tracks, record them down. Then use Soundflow to copy the mix buss plugins you need (Copy Track Data macro), copy them to all the audio tracks, then use Track Bounce to offline bounce all of the stems in one go, and it will include the plugins. Takes about 10-15min.

The only caveat with this is that you have to route any effects to the same aux, like Lead Vocal Verb has to go to Lead Vocal Aux and nowhere else, so you can’t share effects. But if you just create verbs for each thing as you go (or set up in your template) it’s no problem.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Rules for giving notes. 
1) start with what you like, but be brief.
2) “kick up” 👍🏻 “I feel like the kick is too thin” or “boost 50hz” 👎🏻 
3) mixers expect notes, so approach every communication collaboratively. 
4) if something is wrong but you’re not sure what it is, call and discuss. 

Basically not everything needs an explanation, not everything needs to be handled gently. “Kick up, drier verse vocal, longer snare tail, brighter vocal.”

author: cian riordan
content: This “pre-gain staging your template” thing sounds like you’d be backing yourself into even more trouble. Templates are meant to be flexible and you’ll always need to make adjustments to make things work for the track. Let’s say you calibrate your drum bus for 1 dB of gain reduction — what does that do to account for the overall mean volume of those drums? The frequency density? It’s such a weird esoteric metric to try and quantify the signal you’re sending through it. Best thing you could do is setup your template to be able to do broad stroke gain adjustments within, very quickly, to get your chains hitting the way you like.

author: bobby k
content:
Ryan called me yesterday to geek out about a MELD workflow for buss compression. It essentially allows you to compile what’s contributing to the sidechain, and trim up/down certain elements post compression without affecting how the compressor is behaving. I used this for a drum buss yesterday and it was super neat. 

For me if im wanting a slammed buss sound I’m typically gaining down all drum mics that aren’t shells as I lean into the compressor. This let me instead trim up the shells post compression to the same effect. I then messed with just the oheads & crotch feeding the detector to see if the kick and snare was making stuff too pumpy.

I’m still wrapping my mind around this technique and I’d be curious to hear some of you guys weigh in on how you’ve found sidechaining effective in a live drum buss format!

author: sethearnest
content:
I think that's pretty normal when producing something then mixing it yourself. You start to hate "that idiot producer" when you put on the mixing hat, haha. 

If time/deadline allows, sometimes it's nice to take at least a day away from it to mentally separate if possible. Another thing is to treat your production session like you're prepping for an external mixer even though it's yourself in this case, i.e. commit everything and drop it in to a new session. That's maybe overkill, but sometimes when you need a fresh perspective, starting a fresh session like that can help separate the work you've already done w/the work you need to do. 

After that, be ruthless in your assessment of what's actually needed and not (just like you would an outside mix session you got in from someone else). Is that 3rd synth really needed? Maybe the 4 guitars are too much when only 2 are really needed, etc etc. It's of course important to honor the work you've done already and the *reasons* you did X and Y in any given session, but also revisit those "why" reasons and see if you can accomplish those original goals/feelings with a simpler approach if you've ended up with a super-layered thing.

author: sethearnest
content:
For sync most of the time they want actual sub-mixed stems per inst group, not multitracks, so a drum mix, bass, guitars, etc, as separate stems all adding up to the stereo mix. So whatever’s a part of the busses /subgroups adding up to the stereo mix should be left on. 

The reason why: Most of the time they’ll use the stereo mix in my experience, but if something like a shaker or lead synth is wailing away under a dialog moment, or something like a boomer is messing up a sound effect, they’ll bust into the stems to mute those conflicting elements, but they’ll want the song/mix to generally sound the same. 

So for sync stems, they may have deliverable specs already, so doesn’t hurt to ask, but if not, I always try to put myself in the mind of an editor and approach stem splits with the idea of “if it could be distracting, it gets its own stem.” Generally, aside from basic inst groups, I’ll split out high perc stuff, boomer/swooshers/lifters, any leads/solos, and of course vocals always get split lead and BGVs as separate stems.

author: Will Melones
content:
I have two thoughts on this. One is to use balance (often fader automation) to bring attention to a particular track moment by moment. Maybe multiple midrange elements will be competing, but the ear can only focus on one at a time (in addition to the drums, bass, and maybe vocal) so YOU choose and shift the focus!

My second approach is to take two or more of the competing tracks, say kick and bass, and play them together. No point in soloing one. EQ one while listening through it to the other. You may notice that you can subtract quite a bit from the bass without losing its character, but the kick’s punch is improved by the space you’re carving out. I do this a lot with vocals, too—focusing on the vocal inside a dense mix while subtracting from all the other stuff that’s stepping on it. When the lead just finds its home in its own uncongested space, you know you’ve got all the surrounding noise right.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
I have a full routing template including parallels, Inc ei get the files I'll organizettheninto their subgroups and everything gets routed. I just deleted the groups that don't end up with anything in them. I'm on S1 so it's easy to delete a lot of busses/channels in one go w a couple clicks. 

all my main sends are also setup but no actual plugins are loaded besides a clean gain plugin on my mixbus. at this point I don't worry about getting my stem sound to be the same as the mix too much cause I try to get 90% if not more on the tracks themselves. my bus processing tends to be really really light. 

if a group works together I will do all edits I need to each element and just bounce the whole thing  as audio. I then disable and hide the old busses /channels, so I have a way to get back if ever needed.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Towards @peterlabberton's point re objectivity and consistency... I recently wrapped up a slightly unusual 3 year "experiment" on myself.

For various reasons, I decided to narrow down variability in my life and rely heavily on routines. It wasn't scientific at all - the journals wouldn't touch it - but I set up a structured life with the same waking and bedtimes each weekday, similar exercise routines, identical breakfast every weekday at 8am (quantities measured), the same salad (Greek, since you asked) every weekday at 1pm for 18 months (then I switched to a tuna salad I liked and stuck with that for 20 consecutive months), and one of four batch cooked dinners at 6:30pm that I would rotate roughly weekly.

[I've started typing this and I'm realising I'd need to spend far more time than I have right now to demonstrate the depth of my findings and their Nobel prize eligibility, so I'm just going to wrap it up semi-flippantly]

Some takeaways:
- When stuff started sounding bad to me like clockwork at 3:50pm every day, I knew it that it was not the mix turning sour - it was just time to eat my 4pm apple. The sugar would kick in, and hey presto, we're back in vibe town. Removing variables can be helpful in diagnosing issues - the diagnostic problem solving approach one develops as a studio assistant can, to an extent, be applied to ones self.

- Limiting variety mitigates decision fatigue and frees up quite a lot of brain power. I like to think of myself as a less dead Steve Jobs - he wore polo necks, I ate greek salads. We both got a lot done.

author: Maxim
content:
For some activities flow is essential for me (prototyping/design/production) whereas with something like mixing I don’t want to get lost in flow too often. But I couldn’t follow a timer consistently so I try to take breaks whenever I finish a section of work.

So for instance I’ll get the session setup, organized, listen and take a look at some things that are really poking out at me. Then I’ll make a conscious effort to get up and make a coffee or tea. (Short break 10 min tops)

Then I’ll come back and do some editing if needed and start getting the important things to feel/sound right (usually low-end & vocals). Then once I feel like I’ve got then in a good spot I also step away again. This is the hardest break to take for me because it’s just before I could go off into the deep end. But I’ve usually spent an hour listening and tend to lose perspective if I were to go much further. Sometimes I’ll also close the session and work on another project if I’m not in a rush.

But approaching it from a more conscious perspective and removing myself once I’ve hit certain check points is the only thing that’s working for me.

Sometimes Avid Lo-Fi’s saturation can help voice cymbals a little lower (by dulling/darkening).

author: jantrit
content:
I have a general template that has some mix bus/ master bus stuff that’s there but not turned on. Can work a little bit and then kick it into action and see what its gonna do. Then I’ll mix through it for the rest of the mix. Most of the template is just effects busses and print tracks for various pieces of outboard, something to make it super quick to paint without having to make and label everything from scratch each and every mix. Never usually having presets for individual elements but if I’m working on an album sometimes I’ll “build the sonic world” for one track and make a new template for that to import into the sessions moving forward as a bit of a time saver. Tweaks come track to track and record to record, always building new templates specific to the records I’m working on. 

If I’m mixing on the console that kinda becomes the template or preset, I’ll work on a track and build the mix, sit with the client and work revisions and then move onto the next track. Stemming the new track back over the same sorta map on the console and tweaking from there. 

I really try not to make anything to “one size fits all” because you can end up really fucking yourself but it can be nice to have little time savers. You just have to check that it’s making the situation better each and everytime you use them. If it’s not, don’t be precious start from scratch and you’ll get much better quicker results that way.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Would be interested to hear a counter argument, but here’s my take. 

I used to do have a whole template where Vox FX were the only things actually bussed together. 

But over time I’ve realized I use aux sends fx very sparingly. Most of the verbs or delays I’m using are equally as effective on the track with the mix knob, and then all the fx processing is right there on the channel etc. there are downsides but this speeds up the workflow a lot.

author: chrissorem
content: I do analog summing when I mix so  I have daw  groups that feed final daw  output groups that feed my console. Generally I try to not share fx between groups and designated fx that feed the groups. Example: vocal verb or delays outputs go to vocal group. This give an option to eq compress or saturate and melt together if intended. If I don’t want that I send the fx to their final outputs. Example: vocal verb output doesn’t go to vocal Group but to vocal output to console. This is a good workflow for making stems ect as well.

author: wcalebparker
content:
With regard to the “practicing new concepts” thing - for me it depends on the situation. The other day I was working on a live thing and I needed to deal with some bleed. My usual tools weren’t cutting it, so I spent a little time digging into another tool which I thought might do the job well. The deadline isn’t particularly tight so I had the leisure.

I think depending on where you are in your career, it can be really helpful to use someone else’s mixing philosophy as a learning tool, but if people are coming to you for what you do, client projects are probably not the time for that.  

In my head there’s a pretty big difference between exploring a new reverb plug to potentially generate some inspiration and deciding, “on this project I’m SIDE-CHAINING EVERYTHING” when that hasn’t been your thing in the past.

But also, I don’t really think about this that much, and I think you’ll probably have to develop your own feel for what’s appropriate for you. But I wouldn’t  recommend watching MWTM and changing your entire workflow mid project (although I’ve admittedly done this in the past 😂)

In my case I almost always use dry  lead vocals to start.  If people are very particular. I tend to bounce blends, such as a BGV stack or string or horn stack. In particular if there is arrangement automation. I’m not trying to re do what they already like. But if it’s not working for me I’ll re do it. I have a template that has my busses routed and then I get organize and color code. Small sessions take about 15 mins to  prep and bigger sessions about 30 mins max.  If I can I prefer to prep before I plan to mix incase there are any issues with files ect. Sometimes I have an assistant doing it for me. Then I go to town

author: onanisland
content:
yeah ive had it since it came out, same with soothe1 and all similar tools, @Joel "Roomie" Berghult was right. I tend to buy plugins to save time when projects come in. 

In the order I'd range these kind of tools mentioned here:

1. soothe
2. speccraft
3. reso and all others

If you have soothe, you're good imo. 

I liked this one (speccraft) because it gave me more control when I needed to chase a more targeted frequency without affecting the rest (i.e vocals, bass gtr, etc), stuff like that, but I use these kind of tools sparingly. cymbals, egtrs cabs, things like that, almost never on the mixbus because IMHO (don't shoot me), soothe-like tools, affect too much of the signal - suppressing resonances/frequencies "killing the depth" because of the pushing down of reverbs, delays, etc. That is not to say I never use it, there are times for everything, and every tool has its place but yeah. There are people who use it that way and still get GREAT results.
As much as I want to simplify my workflow, 90% of the job is audio janitorial, I go back to simple eq, compression, fader...

I saw another comment asking about Spiff > I don't know if anybody wanted my input on that but nevertheless - I like it sometimes on drums after tape-sims where it kills too much of the transients if I need to drive it more for *reasons* but the sound is lovely (i.e country), bit of spiff after and get best of borth worlds.

author: sethearnest
content:
I use layouts to get my sub groups or VCAs or Folders to populate the S1s. You can program those soft keys at the bottom as layouts. So in my world, the first button is just all the tracks in the session. Button two shows only my Folder sub groups (Drums, Perc, Gtrs, etc) so that’s my go to for that. Button three would be showing only VCAs on the S1, etc. 

So layouts are great once you get them programmed into your template. They save with the session, however, so if you get in a PT session from someone else, your layouts won’t be there. You can save them into your template(s) though, then they’ll always be there for those sessions.

author: ALXCPH
content:
That is true, but I think a good mix still sounds bad in target 😅 and I’ve been in enough bars and restaurants that have playback systems that sound worse than my iPhone in a bathroom only playing out the left speaker. 

And people will still say, “omg I love this song” and start bouncing their head.

 I believe that great songs translate every and anywhere. But fidelity cannot IMO be appreciated in these specific places. 

Ofc there are exceptions. But try eating at a restaurant on a beach promenade in south Spain and the restaurant next to you has a speaker 20 inches from your head blasting a different song. And tell me you think the vocal is warm or the drums are punchy. I think, sadly for general non music fans what they find in music, is less quiteness it’s not even about the song. 

Whereas I think the people who enjoy music, will appreciate that extra punchy drum sound or warm vocal and deep bass. And I believe those people use headphones 80% of the time. They might have a great speaker system at home. But how much time do we really have at home listening to said speakers? Headphones are with us on the go all the time. Everyone I know under 30. Listens primarily on headphones. Or their iPhone speaker. Sometimes a JBL at the beach or park, and every now and then a party speaker at a party while drunk. The ones who really really love music, either have an old vintage speaker set from their parents or a Sonnos/smart speaker type thing. 

I still believe mixing for speakers is important, and @Nomograph Mastering has a great point in speakers translating to headphones easier than vice versa. But I always make sure shit sounds amazing on my AirPods. I’d rather sacrifice something in the speaker than the AirPods. But then again. I don’t have the accolades you do. So I might be shooting myself in the foot. But that is my general philosophy.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I remember a while back while you guys were trying to figure out workflow to maintain edits across mix versions in your mastering work. I suggested a process similar to my DeClick workflow:

blasting the whole file with DeClick on a playlist in ProTools, then selectively comping the DeClicked up to the main playlist. This would leave you with a visual reference of what you did and where.

This would be too heavy handed for your work, but a similar workflow using RX connect - sending trouble spots over to RX, then rendering them back into Pro Tools - would leave a similar visual document of the processing. Maybe you could have playlists for each process.

Maybe not practical in reality, but it seems like one way to attack it.

With just three tracks I’d be too analytical for that clever approach 👆🏻

I’d run versions of each track with all methods available and have them on playlists. Some methods work better for different types of material, different frequency content, different transient preservation… 

I’d do the grunt work then flip between playlists until I got everything feeling the best it could. Suck it and see.

author: Adam Thein
content:
They totally reworked the workflow.  You slap it on anything you want and it will organize sources together that are multi-mic (this doesn't work 100% well and I still group manually).  Then it automatically does all that sidechaining for you in the background as you let it play for 30 seconds, and it spits out a new alignment for you that includes spectral phase rotation.

So far it's been WAY more useful to me than Auto-align v1, but it's still maybe 75% accurate.  Really helpful for DIY engineered files IMO.  Try the demo!

author: Rollmottle
content:
the case is the same digital or analog. it's a helpful tool to keep your gain staging in check. the key is what you calibrate the meter to and where you place it. 

it seems particularly useful on making sure you're hitting known processing chain inputs in their sweet spot. put the meter before any bus processing chain and calibrate the meter to its sweet spot. now you know quickly when you're hitting (or not hitting) the spot where you know it can do the thing in the way you expect it to do the thing. the other really useful one is post bus processing. set the meter on a bus output calibrated to a target level, now you know how gain decisions within the bus are or are not getting you where you want to be. for those working in templates and mixing into known bus processing chains, it seems like it would take a lot of the guess work out of gain staging decisions. it's a very broad stroke tool, but helps me very quickly make decisions on what level something needs to be juiced up or down to. just takes a little upfront work.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: If you match the output level, boosts are cuts and cuts are boosts, and it becomes a question of workflow. If there's dynamic or harmonic processing downstream, then it's about pushing harder into the processing vs. pushing less hard, and that's of course a choice to make. Some EQs (e.g. API) perhaps lend themselves to additive work because the proportional Q is super wide at +-2dB and sometimes people think of subtractive EQ as a tool for more narrow resonance notching, and it's a bit unfamiliar to have -2dB with a Q of 0.5 or whatever.

In theory I get that you want to clip your transients to get them even and then maybe you can have exacting control over how much transient you actually want in a mix with the shaper post clipper, but I've yet to a find a situation where I'd ever want to bring back transient post clipping. Maybe that's because I'm mostly working in the live instrumentation / drum kit space where I'm basically trying to lessen the 20 dB+ of dynamic range on a kick or snare or drumkit at large. Shaving off 6 (or more!) dB of transient on a played snare drum still leaves you with a pretty transient rich snare drum. But I'm still curious about use cases...

author: Deleted User
content: Hey everyone, so a couple months ago I went to a workshop with one of the guys who worked on the loudness standard team for the european broadcast union and it was really interesting how he thinks about all that and how it translates to his mixing workflow in particular. So for those of you who don’t know in broadcast you have to hit a loudness of -23 LUFS +-1dBTP throughout the program. This is especially tricky with live program as you can imagine. But having this fixed loudness target also has a major advantage, it’s that you can have a fixed volume setting on your monitoring and with time you kinda know how loud you’re mixing compared to if you’re mixing for peak loudness, where you’ll always land on different loudness depending on the program. This was the first time I really understood the advantage of that way of working, because with time you’ll be so tuned to the loudness target you’ll be able to really intuit every move. And since -23 gives you boatloads of headroom you can really push things during mixing and then still get the density through clipping/limiting after that. It kinda ties in with what @Nomograph Mastering  was saying about fixed monitoring level. What do you guys think about that?

author: Ross Fortune
content:
This is good to know. The way I approached it was to build the mix with loads of headroom, then when it was all sitting roughly where it wanted to be, I’d alt+drag the input/output of Saturn to wherever it sounded good. It was usually followed by The Glue or another compressor (not always). When I first started using it I was thinking about where the harmonic stages would happen in a (Un)fairchild. I guess probably pre and post compression? There’s probably arguments to compress pre saturation, but I auditioned compression before and after Saturn and preferred it post on that occasion, so that’s how it stayed in the template.

The Pro-Q curve hedged against a tendency I had/have to mix too smiley, and all in all it seemed to make things sound more gooder so the duo lived on in my template… until it didn’t.

author: Matt Huber
content:
I’ve found that they sound identical as long as the DAW settings are identical (pan law being one of the biggest factors in sonic differences). 

That said, every Daw has its own workflow / “logic” / toolset to it that may cause you to work / think differently. I think this is the most important consideration when choosing a DAW for mixing. What DAW creates the best path between the sound in your head to the sound coming out of your speakers?

author: chrissorem
content:
Makes sense and I agree.  Seems like everyone eventually mutes some major groups and solos to hear how things are affecting each other. I like to work with everything in to learn the arrangement and for gain structure reasons I like to start work all in and the biggest section and work backwards. Then as I’m working and I’m fighting something, I’ll start to mute all guitars, or all keys ect…
And see how things are affecting each other and decide who going to give in… and then I’ll listen to just  drums and bass for a while and then I’ll add guitars back and then I’ll Listen to drums and guitars for a bit… and deferent variations of this and I’ll get a deeper understanding of the frequency conflict and I’ll think about  how I want to approach it .

author: JustinLeu
content:
@James Cronier 
-while moving fast- is a bit tricky, I have found that there IS an actual efficiency wall that will eventually be hit. 

Once I factor in revisions/deliverables I have found my max capacity to be “1 song per day” …..even if I finish mix/prep in 5-ish hours, revisions+deliverables will add 2-5hours.

I have a very specific routing template that makes my deliverables all print at once (versions+stems) which requires me to spend a bit more time on the front end to route it all, but I would say on a complicated session it may take 30min?

The routing template when done well is going to leave the delivered files unchanged while also immediately giving me handles to quickly manipulate tracks as needed.

The template took quite a while to dial for my workflow and is always being improved as allowed, but prep/backend will always be the biggest bottle neck.  I am constantly trying to make it more efficient.
