author: Slow Hand
content:
Ok. Trying this out.  I'm not gonna be as thorough this time, because that's a lot of variables to document with photos. So I'll give you my general observations and y'all can take me at my word.

I dropped the input signal to -20dB and then played around with boosting at 100Hz (where my test tone is) to see if the harmonics were different for different EQ band types. I tried a *bell*, a *low shelf*, and a *tilt shelf* to boost.

I was able to boost it +16dB in both *subtle* and *warm* mode before I got any of that harmonic breakup that we started to see in my previous tests as we got approached -0.03 dB. It appears that distortion on *subtle* mode (once again) doesn't kick in at all until the output signal gets within -4dB of 0dB on the output meter. The *amount* I boosted did not matter. The distortion only came when the signal crept close to 0 on the output meter.

All three band types appeared to behave the same when it came to harmonic bloom.
### tl;dr:
I did not detect any difference in behavior with different EQ band types. So they appear to behave the same. It's looking like the breakup doesn't kick in until the output level of the signal is within -4dB of 0dB on the output meter. *Then* they start to break up.

The only exception is the 1st order harmonic at -22dB that appears as soon as you enable *warm* mode. That's always present, no matter how hard you're driving it.

author: GaspardMurph
content:
Here’s what I do regarding loudness : I try to make the client stems hit my stereo bus around where the red line is by the top of the Mute button (very unprofessional that I don’t know)  - so I usually trim my groups (I have a VCA in my template that controls my different instrument buses’ volume). Usually when getting hot stems it’s around -3 / -4db trim. Rarely I get stems too quiet and in these cases I usually clip gain all stems down. 

Then I usually have ozone vintage limiter on at -2.5db which will add a bit of loudness with the auto gain and then set the maximizer to +2dbs.

By the time I’m done doing my thing with bus processing, eqing etc… I’m usually in a good spot lufs wise and then it’s a matter of turning up or down either the makeup gain on my compressor or the output of the maximized

author: BillyC
content: I gotta disagree. Having worked alongside a few A-list guys, I'd say the term "secret" just isn't accurate. They all have the same fundamental tools we do, and any type of mixer tricks you hear about never make or break a given song, they just contribute to one's mixing sensibilities alongside many, many, many other moves. The switching mix bus comps move was a very circumstantial approach that just happened to work for that one Bruno song and I doubt it really happened much after that if at all. The actual knowledge Manny and others at the top of the game have to share is what I relayed and summarized before: understand music deeply, understand artists deeply, and deliver on their vision. Technique discussion is fun, but I don't think anyone here considers this podcast a "mixer secrets exposed" type of forum. There are plenty of shitty YouTubers spewing that content.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m not totally sure. I don’t think metering is going to help you. I’d avoid a mix by numbers approach. Maybe your monitoring needs some attention. A bad room can really make it painfully hard to make confident decisions that translate in the moment or even later in mixing.

Templates to me speed up your workflow not necessarily help you make better decisions if that makes sense. It’s like, setting up several busses you ALWAYS make, so instead of doing 100 keystrokes and commands to get your busses and FX built, two clicks and they’re there for you.

I don’t know what genre / style / level you’re working at, but I’d say just keep working at it. I love recording music because you can ALWAYS do it again. Time is the only thing you have to lose. With enough time, anything is possible. 

That said, looking at a frequency analyzer of a whole mix you like isn’t a horrible thing to do. Maybe you’ll see your mix is way too dark, or way too thin simply.

author: Eric Martin
content:
right, there was a spectral shaper on low mids on one of his buses, but then again on the mix bus it was doing the 1-6k.

I think from what I understand that JC is doing he is controlling the attack so it’s consistent, then using the transient shaper to make sure it’s the same for every hit. It is smart, and for his workflow it’s also fast and easy.

I use compressors a lot, but I’m also working in mostly indie rock with acoustic drums and bass guitars not 808’s and drum machines, which is a drastically different world. I also think I’m doing what most people don’t do and I don’t always love the artifacts of compression so I generally use slow attacks to maintain transients and fast releases to recover quickly (I adjust so that I get the fastest release before audible distortion)

BTW Bruce Swedien while he may have evangelized not using compression don’t underestimate that his greatest works were done to tape and even when you were conservative and didn’t hit tape hard, the transformers going into tape and out of and the tape as a medium itself would peak limit attack heavy instruments like drums

author: BillyC
content: I just import some VCAs, FX returns, mix bus, and print track. All other routing is only done as needed, because routing decisions are really about processing. And those decisions are hard to make until I’ve heard the song and can see what stems I have to work from. I’ve just gotten too many sessions from people where there is so much bussing and subgrouping going on that by the time the vocal gets to the mix bus, it is passed through 3 instances off gullfoss and 4 different compressors and there is zero life in it. It quickly gets out of control. I actually find minimal bussing to be a quicker workflow because I don’t have to follow a whole series of subgroups to know the entire processing chain on a given audio source when I’m trying to make a tweak, nor will that tweak affect any other element that is sitting just fine. That’s just my brain though.

author: BillyC
content: I do kinda fuck with this as a default approach, but not because it's "EQing your speakers". Managing contrast well in a mix generally makes for a more immersive feel (even in stereo), and you do lose a bit of contrast between elements with every bit of processing that's on the entire mix bus. So I tend to have better results addressing EQ inside the mix first rather than beginning the mix with some preset curve that is likely to work against me.

author: Will Melones

If you REALLY want to simulate a soundstage, four zone reverbs with *mostly* similar settings—rear left, rear right, front left, front right. I’m imagining this as a relatively acoustic thing, and this approach may not apply to much else…

author: JakeTB
content:
Been struggling on an approach concept recently and wanted to see if y’all have any input-

I find myself in a constant tug-of-war between flow state and mindful mix moves. On the one hand, I don’t want to overthink shit, but if I just go into a mix in a flow state, it seems to just be an endless flow of tweaks: One move changes the relationship between an element, which needs a fix which changes another element, etc.

To combat this, I started trying to be more mindful: taking a pen and notepad and listening through the rough and noting the changes I want made, making them, doing another listen down to re-evaluate, etc.

The first approach lead to unnecessarily long, roundabout ways to my destination; and the second approach left me with undercooked, lifeless mixes. So the flow state is maladaptive but the analytical approach is stale (and super unfun as the mixer). Am I the only one with this dilemma?

author: spectrummasters
content: I can relate to this . I think first impression notes are a great tool and I’m challenging myself to “do less “ not more to roughs:demos . Often times when I’m tracking vocals it is to a two track (rnb/hip-hop) and I’ve learnt that just about any “vocal sound “ I want to go for I better get it whilst we are tracking because the artists always want a rough vocal mix to go away with at end of session . Invariably , whatever that rough sounds like I can’t stray away from (for good or bad ) once they’ve heard it . And then when it comes to a final mix , it gets even more complicated getting the actual stems for the two track and mixing it all down with the vocal tracks as it often (imo) sounds better but doesn’t feel the same as that on the day rough vocal mix to the two track . I realised there’s no way I can get an artist to unhear that first  rough mix and I’m wasting hours mixing it all over again with the stems , like I’m re inventing a wheel no one wants . I’ve noticed @Bainz_  telling @oaklandmatt he had the same issues with thugs punk album and also have heard Jason Goldberg and Stuart white embracing the idea that you’re possibly mixing the final mix/pre master as you track . It’s a very raw and quick approach and it does keep you miles away from overmixing something . I embraced it as a workflow only recently and it’s less stressful than working your ass off on a “perfect” mix only to get back they prefer the vibe of the first day mix .   top tips not to overmix I am meditating on currently are : don’t lose your dynamics , watch your phase relationships don’t change , leave some mistakes in , automate more than compress and be quick

author: JakeTB
content:
I had to step away mid-convo for that pesky “real life” stuff, but I really appreciate everyone’s insight. This discord is a great place 🙂 

Although most the conversation didn’t end up tackling what I am looking to weed out, it was extremely helpful in the “hundred ways not to make a lightbulb” sense. 

Conclusion I’ve come to is that the flow state approach, monitoring practices, and technical chops are not the issue; the issue lies with better honing my sense for “the thing” that can make the record a bit more potent.

author: Zack Hames
content:
What @AlexL is on point and I’ve had a lot of the same thoughts as you but here’s my experience:

You can run your session at a very high buffer size which makes your session run smoothly while having low latency for tracking. You can use DSP plugins while tracking with this high buffer size and have low latency. 

That said, I was doing 24 track recording at 128 buffer size on a mac trash can (64 gig ram) with native plugins with no issue. Then i started working at the studio I’m at now and it’s an older mac pro and we have an apogee symphony with HDX, so I utilize that workflow there: using only dsp plugins and having the buffer size high. (While tracking).

I think it's partly because school systems don't teach us to ask open questions. A lot of times we are just given information. So people may find more comfort in "do this, do that" or "this is the solution" approach but that doesn't necessarily mean it's not compatible. It just needs a bit of encouragement to see value in finding one's own answers to things, which I think contributes to us having more patience to sit with the questions. 

But conservative tendencies seem to be a trait that is more on the inherit side of the spectrum. And conservative tendencies make it a bit difficult to accept having one's view, lifestyle, habits in thought processes shaken up by an open question with no definitive answers.

author: cuba1956
content:
Dear friends, I have a question about sidechain in the stereo compression. Probably a weird one, but I think I'm missing something.
I've been looking into SSL Bus comp schematic — there are several going around the internet and based on what I see in SSL 500 unit are quite interesting in a way how the sidechain envelope follower is generated.
There are several approaches I see in various models:
1. Original SSL mixes left and right channels with OR principle — basically the envelope is generated based on the strongest signal coming from either L or R channels. 
2. Some of the models suggest mixing left and right channels — essentially you get the average signal between channels which is then generates into an envelope.
3. True stereo (or rather dual mono with a single set of settings) — which calculates envelopes for the left and right channels independently.
Some SSL comp models have a switch to trigger between various modes, but if I understand correctly, none of the SSL original models have used true stereo (fully independant) sidechain processing.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Further musings on appropriate crediting (and they are just that, I’m not bitter about this project at all, just thinking for down the line):

If other artists like the sound (and sounds) of these tracks, they’ll probably approach the people hired to produce the album to work on theirs. But in reality, those producers made demos that hinted at the sound, rather than actually accomplishing it.

Is it better to be the hero mixer who producers know they can hand off a stone to and have it come back a diamond? Then the mixer gets their repeat custom and recommendations to their producer peers, right?

The cost here is setting a precedent for having stones turn up on your desk that you then always have to chisel, sand, and polish. **Forever…** Cian’s talked about this before - wanting to get feet back on the studio floor so he can just engineer things the way he wants to hear them.

Option B: the mixer digs their heels in and makes sure that everyone knows the record sounds how it does because they made it sound that way. If you want yours to have the same care taken, then get them to produce your record?

author: LAPhill
content:
I've stumbled upon a workflow that's working really well for me, but might be impossible for record folks. I'm deep into the mix on a score I'm finishing up, and I need to deliver stems to the client (it's a video game, and stems will turn on/off depending on various factors). Since I'm getting pretty wide splits from the mixer, I'm able to save him the hassle of my tweaky notes and once the sonics of the track are nailed down, he sends me stems and I can do my stupid "this flute phrase should be a bit louder," "this guitar is more important in the blend than the piano here," etc. It keeps the mixer focused on the big moves and I spare him an hour per-cue of my nitpickyness. 

We have a lot of trust, though. And I would imagine that the risk is too high that people will go in and completely fuck things up if you were delivering stems (not to mention the master bus processing factor)

author: LAPhill

author: Edward Rivera
content: It should be a fairly linear approach, and if it's not working in the end, you gotta look down the pipeline and find the worse offenders. A good drum recording should slam without mixing. And if you have a slamming rhythm section going on that's now obfuscated by bringing up the rest of the mix, find out who's the culprit. Or rather than try to make everything slam all the time, figure out what the heartbeat of the song is, and make that slam. If it's the vocal, do that. If it's a keyboard hook, do that

author: Ross Fortune
content:
[Apologies for long message, I’m thinking out loud but also detail is probably useful] Gearing up to mix a live album with a heap of songs (tbc but potentially 23 in one show).

The last time I did something like this, it was low channel count -   a couple of acoustics, one or two vocals, maybe a keyboard per song. I mixed the whole thing in one Pro Tools session, with a separate set of channels for each song which I’d then make inactive and move onto the next song. When printing the continuous mix at the end, I’d make active two songs at a time for any overlap, and constructed the long printed mix like that.

In this case though, there are multimiced drums, bass, electric guitars, keyboards, vocals. The recordings are good (from the stereo board mixes I’ve heard) and the scale is such that I want to have the fidelity I’d approach a studio record with, and the room to shape an identity for each song (while still sounding like they all happened on the same stage on the same night) so I’m thinking to use my usual elaborate drum mix routing with parallels etc, all the bells and whistles.

This complexity would put me off mixing 23 songs in one session, but I’m thinking of the inevitable crunch at the end of the project and the potential frustration of jumping between sessions.

Am I thinking too deeply about this? Should I just get a drum sound and leave it there for 23 tracks, with a few rides here and there?

Not much experience with this stuff so any thoughts would be very welcome please!

author: Will Melones
content:
I have nowhere near the experience you do, but I’d approach this in one session. So when you get to song 16 and discover that perfect kick sound, or get a note from the artist that the bass could come up 2dB for the whole show, you’re not opening 23 sessions to revise.

But my approach would also be one set of tracks from beginning to end, just like you’re mixing it live, and prepare to automate. What made you choose a separate set of channels for each song?

author: montrose recording
content: try starting a mix with a trim at the top of your master insert and then something later in your chain adding a lot of gain like 10-12 db before ur limiter / leveler.  ive found that starting from a situation like this helps me stay way far away from clipping early in the chain.  it also lets me keep my levels with analog inserts on the master fader in a comfortable headroom zone.  the key part of the above idea for me is starting that way, not building it in later.

author: lystell
content:
On the topic of EQ
I'm doing some projects now that are live drums driven so to speak. I'm trying to up my game both when it comes to recording and mixing. 
My instinct when it comes to EQ is to subtract. In a way, it feels logical to me. Let's say I don't like the sound on a snare around 400hZ. Then my brain goes - let's remove that. 
I've been digging deeper lately into the API style of EQ and it occurred to me that when going through the preset list -  most of the presets were doing additive stuff. I find this very interesting and when it comes to "surgical sounddesign",  a new workflow for me. Like - I don't like the low mid on this snare. Let's boost the top instead. 
It feels somewhat backward but I can see some good things coming of it. 
How's your workflow?

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
Re: Limiter, to the extent that little micro-transients spike up post-compression, I see what happens if I shave them off a few dB w/ a limiter. Either it sounds better or it doesn't.

Re: 15dB, I really don't think it's a ton of gain reduction, assuming we're talking about a modern commercial genre of music. If it sounds bad, I'll back it off. Or if the producer hit it hard already, I won't hit it as hard on my end. Or maybe some songs call for a gentler approach. But I'm not gonna operate from a place of pre-emptive worry.

content: I have a mix template that has the drums setup all the way I like — one clean bus, one compression bus, and one distortion bus. Question for y'all who've worked in TV audio before:

I've got a gig writing several 90 sec tracks for a TV program. I'm writing half-a-dozen ballroom tracks (ballroom as in drag) for their queens. So the gig is calling for club music. My question is this: Should I mix these records like they're an album cut (read: loud/hot) or should I approach the mix knowing that there's going to be available headroom in the TV audio mix?

It's been my experience that loud/squashed records end up sounding puny in TV programming because the broadcast mixers turn it down. If I mix them hot they'll sound banging on set while they're filming, but this may be at the expense of impact in the final broadcast mix when it's turned down.

just my 2 cents, i've tried just about every de-esser, and the Lindell 902 de-esser is the most "just does what its supposed to" imo. Its also very low CPU.

author: Rob Domos
content:
I have absolutely used rx to pitch shift things, and even to pitch shift things gradually over time, ie. a choir that’s going flat over time on a chord. I make it drift sharper over time to compensate and they sound mostly in tune. It’s great for serato style repitching. 

If you want to do melodyne style detail work it would be beyond clunky workflow wise and usually not the best tool

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. Less and less these days. A full mix might only have 2-3 effects sends on it. I've moved to a workflow where each channel (or group of instruments) get their own "send effects" right on the channel.

This is partly because a lot of the tools I use now include EQ and dynamics processing that allow me to sculpt within the plugin, and it's is partly because Ableton's rack tools enable me to easily set up parallel processing for effects within the channel without the need to mult-out or send the instrument to separate channels. It's way more efficient and easy to manage my sessions now.

author: spectrummasters
content:
fwiw, im in a good position to experiment currently as i get quick money on site and then have the time where i dont have the recall/revisions/deadlines workflow demands that most talented / industry people here do, so i  have taken the last year out to spend a lot of time thinking, learning and planning how to offer something fresh as a mixer here in Lonoon and i dont want to sound like anyone else. So ,im ditching gullfosses and soothes and spectral shapers and MB's..and im breaking my buses out to h/w mixers and boxes so that i can hopefully induce some electromagnetic phenomena or some "accidental" errors , like  my two year old coming in and turning knobs on the gear without me seeing (as he does) and then i mix through it , unknowingly....and ive introduced something wrong, something a perfect alogirthm could never give me ....something........difffffferent. Im v. bored atm with listening to perfect productions and mixes. Imho they are delicious and tasty and  malnourishing like McDonalds.

Imho, the sound of  Robert Johnson recorded, singing crossroads in a shack somewhere a 100 years ago will still outlast the bombastic incredibly perfect production/mixes i feel encouraged to mimic today. i feel like perfection has been overdone at this point. Lets f things up

it might be a naff idea but , where im at....since doing band stuff....that tom elmhirst quote about there being no perfect mix....and the mix is the mix that happened at the moment where eevryone in the room agreed was it......and not to be touched again...this is what im fascinated with at the mo....and doing the print with me and the drummer on my current mixes pushing the analogue faders (with the busses stemmed out of the daw) together. Making it performative and transient

author: cian riordan
content: I've tried to embrace top-down mixing over the past year more and more as its really what clients want. But I would never want my work to fall apart if I wasn't able to take it off the master chain and not be close to the mark... I still try and make these decisions further upstream in the mix.

author: cian riordan
content: If clients deliver a very well baked top-down rough mix, then it's extremely difficult to operate outside of that construct. If somebody delivers a song to mix and it has very mild, conservative processing and doesn't really sound in the ballpark, then that's my green light to do whatever I see fit.

author: sethearnest
content:
Gut check: I have two producers and four artists happy with a many-featured-artists mix, and the team prefers my LoudRef over the mastering engineer's v1 (Yes I also sent my LoudRef and limiter settings). The mastering engineer is apparently unable to tweak and says it's due to their gear setup and suggested I tweak the mix to better fit their chain. I'll be working blind as I have no clue what this immutable mastering chain is. 

I'm generally a "jump; how high?" type, so I'll tweak it b/c, hey, maybe it'll get better. I'm no Tchad. 

Here's the gut check: I want to say something like, "Happy to tweak, but let's avoid back-and-forth revisions," but is it better to just go whatever mile after going the inch? I'm envisioning a cycle of revisions with me trying to hit an unknown bullseye here which sounds messy, so would like to establish a boundary, but looking for a gut check if it's maybe a dumb boundary to try to establish. 

(My very strongly held opinion about this unknown mastering engineer's approach on this isn't something I want to try to prosecute w/the team -- I just want to be smart w/r/t when to defend a mix everyone's happy with vs. when to just jump.)

author: EliHeathMusic
content:
I’ve been thinking a lot about how I deal with resonance and unwanted harshness recently and would love to hear about how you all approach this (and maybe more broadly how you think about restraint and taste when using modern plugins). We have so many powerful tools at this point for cleaning up audio (eq, rx, soothe, spectral shaper, de-essing, etc) but when I listen closely to a lot of my favorite recordings from the last 70 years I’ll hear all sorts of weird resonances and abnormalities. 

Over time I’ve been getting better at finding a balance of how far to go with these tools and have also become aware of how easy it can be to go overboard sometimes. Beyond reps and intuition, are there things that have helped you hone in on this? And are you consciously adjusting your “threshold” based on the music or genre you’re working with or do you have a general taste for how you like to hear things regardless of the style and use other tools to get the character and vibe you’re going for.

In other words, do you think about how far you go with these tools as a creative and stylistic decision or more of a functional one?

author: Josh Bowman
content:
Oooff feel your pain that’s rough. This happens to me from time to time, not always that extreme tho.

Generally my first move is to listen while bypassing each thing and trying to identify what it’s making better and what gets worse, then if I decide to try and keep some of them I’ll attempt to move some of those plugs off the main mix buss and back onto a subgroup or instrumental buss. But no matter what it ends up with me looping sections and rebuilding the mix to match the rough vibe before I get into the actual creative fun part of the mix.

I have one producer i work with often who mixes into a comp on his all vocal buss and it’s slow and hitting like 3-6 db compression. It totally bones me while mixing so I usually end up rebalancing all the vocals section by section to match his mix before I “start mixing”. 

Sometimes I’ll just work into their buss shit and bypass the stuff/bands of each of plug that are only hurting and not helping. 

Real can of worms tbh. 

Last week I ran into the vocal buss issue- luckily it was a comp w side chain input so I did try out the sidechain, I pre fader sent all the tracks feeding it while copying automation to that send, then used a master fader to match the buss sc level to the original comps gain reduction  and it worked well in that situation and untied my hands while saving me from a whole vocal rebalance session. First time that approach ever actually worked though for me tbh. If its a comp that drums are driving into i find the sc input doesnt end up feeling the same usually.

author: cian riordan
content: But to answer your question, because it's likely similar to my workflow -- when a session comes in to mix, it'll likely have the producer's mix bus on there. It makes sense to keep that intact in the session to reference it while you build up your own, audition alternate options, etc.

For some, tuning out the noise and just getting to work is the ticket. For others, it's hoovering in everything and sifting through it all to assemble it into something until you have your own. Part of me wants to say that tuning out what everyone else is doing and developing your own approach might save you a lot of unnecessary banging your head against the wall trying to fit square pegs into round holes. author: @lmmaudio
content: Man, interesting. I do the same gentle filtering about 3dB/oct on the high-end at 18k or so; but only on the Mid part of the signal and at the same time go additive eq on the Sides, but with dynamic mode. Normally on latin music styles like salsa, boleros and more traditional genres this move behaves very well opening the top end and preserving the sheen of the transients; which are normally a lot. Good to know I'm not the only one going with this approach.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Oh interesting - For some reason my journey has led to me only reaching for the CLA76 on a parallel for the bass, but I should try it again in other contexts.

In case anyone would wanna try my approach to getting bass to play nice across more speakers / phones:

- I use the 20 ratio bluey to squash a bass parallel. Then I drive it through the free TSC 808 plugin for further emphasize the harmonics the bluey brings out. (EQ too)
- Then, I use Audreio on the master to play the mix through my phone instead of my monitors. Once on the phone, you can blend the parallel with the bass in a way where there’s little to no audible difference on a monitor, but the illusion of a bass can be heard through the harmonics playing on the phone.
- It’s a balancing act, but there’s almost always a nice sweet spot to be found where it doesn’t change the quality of the sound enough to be intrusively perceived on HD speakers, while giving life to the bass on lesser speakers.

This has helped my bass translate to more systems, and is the only time I find myself wanting to use the CLA76.

author: cian riordan
content: FWIW, I love a loud mix... and am often on the maybe-too-loud side of things. But first thing I do when I pull up something to mix is listen down to the ref and see where it's sitting. If it's already blasting, I'll just turn it down to where I want to ballpark, and then start working on my mix -- using the lowered rough as a reference. Sometimes we overthink the rough and it could really just be that some mope slapped a limiter on and slammed it before printing. It doesn't always have to be the target for your mix.

I usually approach mixes with that “work with what’s there” mindset, but when the artist or producer gives me the green light to dig in, I’ll often do some post-production right in the mix stage, just muting stuff, adding little elements I feel are missing, building transitions or breaks, that kind of thing. author: N
content:
I understand the perspective of (lufs don’t matter) however I want some consistency amongst my songs AND to be sufficiently loud compared to others.

I am competent of achieving very loud mixes however the introduction of artifacts bothers me. Usually I’m low passing with ISOL8 to listen for limiting/clipping clicks. These artifacts are unable to be heard unless I have a low pass filter active but I theorize that they, along with the extreme compression subconsciously degrade the listening experience by discretely assaulting your ears to the point of needing to take a break from listening. 

My music can be related sonically to clara la sans “another night” give or take more or less busy. (Keep in mind her stuff is cranked to the point of audible artifacts sitting around -7ish lufs integrated across the chorus).

I arrange the mix well and leave 1db of headroom for summing on individual instruments whilst they are loud enough for my target of -10 LUFi across the chorus, meaning my mix is actually 1db louder than -10 with space to sum on the pre master bus. Leaving headroom means I can introduce less artifacts at the cost of having to squeeze the dynamic range of individual instruments more than otherwise.

My issue is that If I want to aim for let’s say -8LUFSi across the chorus in a relatively clean way with minimal artifacts, I’m forced to squeeze the mix to -7.

I’d love to hear y’all thoughts on whether or not technically inaudible artifacts/distortion matter and whether or not it’s really worth for me to squeeze my mix 2db more in the name of competitive loudness?

Ps. Please bear with me as I am trying to figure this all out solo. Feel free to criticize my approach.
